itemDescription: British army officer and colonial administrator

wikipedia_page.main: Sir Robert Miller Mundy  (1813–1892) was a British soldier and colonial civil servant. He was the Lieutenant-Governor of Grenada.

link_mentions.page: List of colonial governors and administrators of Grenada
List of colonial governors and administrators of British Honduras

response: Miller never married. He died at Barbados at the age of 48. His uncle Robert Miller Mundy had a colonial career in the West Indies. His nephew Arthur Wilmot played cricket for Derbyshire.
* Robert Miller Mundy (1813–1892), who married Isabella Leyborne-Popham, daughter of General Edward William Leyborne-Popham.
*Major Robert Miller Mundy  lately Lieutenant-Governor of the Colony of British Honduras
Sir Robert Miller Mundy KCMG (1813 – 22 March 1892), Lieutenant-Governor of Grenada, was his half-brother.

Catherine (nee Coffin) was born in Boston, Massachusetts in 1769. She was the sister of Sir Isaac Coffin.Graves, A. 1899 “A history of the works of Sir Joshua Reynolds, P.R.A” Online reference She married twice. Her first husband was Richard Barwell, a trader in the East India Company who amassed a large fortune. He died in 1804 and in 1811 Catherine married Edward Miller Mundy of Shipley Hall. Two years later the couple had one son Robert Miller Mundy.

Catherine died in 1847. There is a memorial window in her honour in St John the Baptist's Church, Westbourne. Her son Sir Robert Miller Mundy (1813-1892) inherited the house. He and his family lived at Hollybank House for the next sixty years. In 1841 he married Isabella Leyborne Popham who was the daughter of General Edward William Leyborne Popham.Burkes Genealogical and Heraldic History of the Landed Gentry”, 1882. p. 1141. Online reference The couple had ten children – nine daughters and one son. In 1863 he was appointed Lieutenant Governor of Grenada and the house was rented for many years. The advertisement for this is shown. During this time Rear Admiral the Honourable Thomas Alexander Pakenham was the tenant.The Gentlemans Magazine 1866, p.578. Online reference He was the 3rd son of the 2nd Earl of Longford. His wife who he married in 1853 was Sophia Frances Sykes who was the daughter of Sir Tatton Sykes. The couple are recorded in the 1871 Census as living at Hollybank House with four of their children, a housekeeper, a butler, a footman, a ladies’ maid, and four maids.

After his retirement in 1877 Sir Robert Miller Mundy returned to Hollybank House. The 1881 Census shows the couple living there with two daughters and five servants. Robert died in 1892The Peerage website. Online reference and his wife Isabella and unmarried daughter Eleanor continued to live there until Isabella’s death in 1906. In 1907 the house was sold and the advertisement for the sale is shown at this reference.Advertisement for the sale of Hollybank House in 1907. Online reference
